details.title: Connected Vehicle Diagnostics and Prognostics, Concept, and Initial Practice
details.standardTitle: Connected Vehicle Diagnostics and Prognostics, Concept, and Initial Practice

p: Yilu Zhang (S'99–M'02–SM'08) received his B.S., and M.S. degrees in Electrical Engineering from Zhejiang University, China, in 1994, and 1997, respectively; and his Ph.D. degree in Computer Science from Michigan State University in 2002. He joined the R&D center of General Motors Co. at Warren, Michigan in 2002, and currently holds a position of Senior Researcher. Dr. Zhang is a Senior Member of IEEE, a member of SAE, and a member of Sigma Xi international honor society. He served as an Associate Editor of International Journal of Humanoid Robotics from 2003 to 2007, the Publication Chair for IEEE 8th International Conference on Development and Learning 2009, and a member of the Autonomous Mental Development Technical Committee of the IEEE Computational Intelligence Society. He was the President of the Sigma Xi GM R&D Chapter in 2006. Dr. Zhang's research interests include machine learning, diagnosis and prognosis, speech/image processing, human machine interactions, and their applications. He has published 30+ technical papers in these areas. He has two US patents and sixteen pending patents, of which ten are in the area of vehicle diagnosis and prognosis.

authors.affiliation: Electr. & Controls Integration Lab., GM Res. & Dev., Warren, MI
authors.name: Yilu Zhang

p: Gary W. Gantt Jr. received his BSEE in electrical engineering from Wayne State University, Detroit, Michigan in 2002. He joined General Motors' Software Test and Validation group upon graduating, after completing 3 internships with General Motors during his college years. from there, he went on to become the Lead Systems/Design Release Engineer for the system he was previously responsible for validating Electrical Power Management. It was here that he gained experience in remote vehicle diagnostics and prognostics. Mr. Gantt is currently a Program Manager with one of General Motors key suppliers, American Axle & Manufacturing, where he is responsible for product development on GM projects. His professional interests include charging systems, advanced energy and hybrid technology, drive train systems, and generally learning all he can about the vehicle electrical systems and environment.
Mark J. Rychlinski is the Engineering Group Manager of Energy Management and Chassis Systems in GM Global Engineering.

Ryan M Edwards (Senior Systems Engineer, OnStar) received his B.S. in Computer Engineering from Michigan State University in 2000. Since joining the advanced systems development group at OnStar in 2007, he has worked on several key services and enablers that utilize the telematics connection to the vehicle. Prior to joining OnStar, he had worked as a software engineer with various automotive suppliers including Continental Automotive, and Motorola Automotive, designing and developing solutions for interior electronics.

John J Correia (Technical Fellow and Engineering Group Manager, OnStar Advanced Systems Development) received his B.S. in Electrical Engineering from University of Michigan, Dearborn in 1989, and MBA from University of Michigan in 1999. He has held a number of technical management roles in the advanced development area of OnStar since 2001, and has initiated or led several significant services that exploit a wireless data connection to GM's vehicles. Prior to joining OnStar, he held a variety of technical and business process positions at Ford Motor Company, and later Visteon Automotive Systems in the area of infotainment and telematics.

Calvin E. Wolf (P.E.) received his B.S. in Electrical Engineering from Lawrence Technological University in 1991. He has earned both a M.S.E. degree from Purdue in 1995, and an M.S.E.S. degree from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in 2000. He has worked in the Electrical department at General Motors in Warren, MI since 1991, and he holds the title of Senior Project Engineer. His research interests include vehicle data mining, and automotive telematics.

details.abstract: We propose a new concept of Connected Vehicle Diagnostics and Prognostics (CVDP) to address some of the challenges in vehicle system fault diagnostics and prognosis, such as the diagnostics of unexpected new faults, and infrequent or intermittent faults. As an initial practice, this concept has been implemented in the vehicle design validation process at GM. This paper presents the implementation details, and some case studies.

links.abstract: Theory and applications of model-based fault diagnosis have progressed significantly in the last four decades. In addition, there has been increased use of model-based design and testing in the automotive industry to reduce design errors, perform rapid prototyping, and hardware-in-the-loop simulation (HILS). This paper presents a new model-based diagnostic development process for automotive engine control systems. This process seamlessly employs a graph-based dependency model and mathematical mo...

links.abstract: Automotive engines is an important application for model-based diagnosis because of legislative regulations. A diagnosis system for the air-intake system of a turbo-charged engine is constructed. The design is made in a systematic way and follows a framework of hypothesis testing. Different types of sensor faults and leakages are considered. It is shown how many different types of fault models, e.g., additive and multiplicative faults, can be used within one common diagnosis system, and using th...

links.abstract: Fault management is critical for a vehicle active safety system. Since a sensor fault may not always be detectable by a sensor self-test or an electronic monitoring system whose detection often relies on out-of-range signals, a redundancy check is warranted for the detection of an in-range signal fault. In this paper, an in-vehicle roll rate sensor failure detection scheme utilizing analytical redundancy is presented. The vehicle is assumed to be equipped with a steering wheel angle sensor, a ya...

links.abstract: In recent years, passenger vehicle product development faces great challenges to maintain high vehicle quality due to the proliferation of Electronics, Control and Software (ECS) features and the resultant system complexity. Quickly detecting and trouble-shooting faults of integrated vehicle systems during the validation stage in a key to enhancing vehicle quality. In this paper, we present a feasibilty study of Vehicle Design Validation via Remote Vehicle Diagnosis (VDV-via-RVD) and its applica...

context.text: In a previous publication [7] we presented some early experiment results, using the idea of CVDP.
Since the publication of [7] an initial practice of CVDP has passed the stage of concept-proof, and has been deployed in production at GM.

links.abstract: The paper describes our research in vehicle signal fault diagnosis. A modern vehicle has embedded sensors, controllers and computer modules that collect a large number of different signals. These signals, ranging from simple binary modes to extremely complex spark timing signals, interact with each other either directly or indirectly. Modern vehicle fault diagnostics very much depend upon the input from vehicle signal diagnostics. Modeling vehicle engine diagnostics as a signal fault diagnostic ...
